docs.title: AGEN
docs.text:
• 20+ Specialist Agents

    From Frontend Experts to Security Auditors, switch personas instantly with a single command. agen init does the heavy lifting.

  • Modular Skills

    Mix and match capabilities like Docker, React, or Penetration Testing. Agents are composable and reusable across projects.

  • Multi-IDE Support

    One configuration, tailored output for Cursor, Windsurf, Zed, and Antigravity. Never write a system prompt manually again.

  • Health & Verify

    Ensure your project's agent configuration is valid, secure, and up-to-date with agen verify.

docs.title: The Universal AI Agent Manager
docs.text:
Standardize, share, and manage your AI coding assistants across any IDE. One CLI to rule them all.

Get Started View Commands

graph LR
    A[AGEN CLI] -->|Init| B[Project Config]

docs.title: Why use AGEN?
docs.text:
AI coding assistants are powerful, but managing their "system prompts" (or personalities) is a mess. You copy-paste text files, lose track of versions, and struggle to share successful prompts with your team.

AGEN solves this by treating Agent Templates like packages.

"It's like npm for your AI's personality."

docs.title: Advanced Usage
docs.text: This guide covers advanced AGEN features for power users.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Variable Description Default AGEN_NO_COLOR Disable colored output false AGEN_DEBUG Enable verbose debug logging false AGEN_CONFIG_DIR Override config directory location System default AGEN_CACHE_DIR Override cache directory location System default

Example: 

AGEN_DEBUG=true agen init --verbose

docs.title: Profile Management
docs.text: Profiles save specific configurations (IDE + Agents + Skills) for reuse.

docs.title: Save and Load
docs.text:
# Save current config as profile
agen profile save my-web-stack

# Apply profile to new project
agen profile load my-web-stack

docs.title: Export and Share
docs.text:
# Export profile as JSON
agen profile export my-web-stack > web-stack.json

# Share with team, they import with:
agen profile import web-stack.json

See Profiles for detailed documentation.

docs.title: Custom Templates
docs.text: Override built-in templates or add your own.

docs.title: Local Template Directory
docs.text:
Create a local template directory:

mkdir -p ~/.agen-templates/agents
mkdir -p ~/.agen-templates/skills

docs.title: Adding Custom Agent
docs.text:
Create ~/.agen-templates/agents/my-agent.md:

---
name: my-agent
description: My custom agent for specific tasks
tools: Read, Grep, Edit, Write
skills: clean-code
---

# My Custom Agent

You are a specialized agent for...

docs.title: Priority Order
docs.text:
AGEN loads templates in priority order: 1. Local overrides (~/.agen-templates/) 2. Installed plugins 3. Embedded templates (built-in)

First match wins.

docs.title: Conflict Resolution
docs.text: When running agen update, AGEN handles conflicts intelligently.

docs.title: Behavior
docs.text: Scenario Action Template unchanged locally Updated automatically Template modified locally Skipped (warning shown) New template available Added --force flag used All templates overwritten

docs.title: Checking Conflicts
docs.text:
# See what would be updated
agen update --dry-run

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
name: AGEN Validation

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  validate:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Install AGEN
        run: |
          curl -L https://github.com/eshanized/agen/releases/latest/download/agen_linux_amd64.tar.gz | tar xz
          sudo mv agen /usr/local/bin/

      - name: Validate Configuration
        run: agen team validate --strict

      - name: Run Verification
        run: agen verify

docs.title: GitLab CI
docs.text:
agen-validate:
  stage: test
  script:
    - curl -L https://github.com/eshanized/agen/releases/latest/download/agen_linux_amd64.tar.gz | tar xz
    - ./agen team validate
    - ./agen verify

docs.title: Pre-commit Hook
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# .git/hooks/pre-commit

if command -v agen &> /dev/null; then
  if ! agen team validate --quiet 2>/dev/null; then
    echo "❌ Team validation failed"
    exit 1
  fi
fi

exit 0

docs.title: Monorepo Configuration
docs.text:
For monorepos with multiple projects:

my-monorepo/
├── .agen-team.json       # Shared team config
├── packages/
│   ├── frontend/
│   │   └── .agent/       # Frontend-specific agents
│   ├── backend/
│   │   └── .agent/       # Backend-specific agents
│   └── shared/
│       └── .agent/       # Shared utilities

docs.title: Per-Project Initialization
docs.text:
# Initialize each package separately
cd packages/frontend
agen init --agents frontend-specialist,test-engineer

cd ../backend
agen init --agents backend-specialist,security-auditor

docs.title: Adding Project-Specific Scripts
docs.text:
Create scripts in .agent/scripts/:

mkdir -p .agent/scripts

Add my-check.py:

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""Custom verification script."""

import sys
import os

def main():
    errors = []

    # Your custom checks here
    if not os.path.exists("README.md"):
        errors.append("Missing README.md")

    if errors:
        print("❌ Errors found:")
        for e in errors:
            print(f"  • {e}")
        return 1

    print("✅ All checks passed")
    return 0

if __name__ == "__main__":
    sys.exit(main())

docs.title: Running Custom Scripts
docs.text: python .agent/scripts/my-check.py

docs.title: Creating a Plugin
docs.text:
agen plugin create my-plugin --type bundle

This generates:

my-plugin/
├── plugin.json
├── agents/
│   └── my-agent.md
├── skills/
│   └── my-skill/
│       └── SKILL.md
└── README.md

docs.title: Testing Locally
docs.text:
# Install from local path
agen plugin install ./my-plugin

# Verify it's installed
agen plugin list

# Test in a project
agen init --agents my-agent

See Plugin System for detailed documentation.

docs.title: Adding Custom Sources
docs.text:
# Add a custom template repository
agen remote add company https://github.com/company/agen-templates

# Fetch templates
agen remote fetch

# List remotes
agen remote list

docs.title: Private Repositories
docs.text:
For private repos, configure authentication:

# Using GitHub token
export GITHUB_TOKEN=ghp_xxxxx
agen remote add private https://github.com/company/private-templates

docs.title: Verbose Output
docs.text: agen init --verbose

docs.title: Debug Logging
docs.text: AGEN_DEBUG=true agen init 2>&1 | tee debug.log

docs.title: Checking Configuration
docs.text:
# View current config
agen config list

# Check profiles
agen profile list

# Check plugins
agen plugin list

docs.title: Performance Tips
docs.text:
1. Use --dry-run: Preview changes before applying
  2. Save Profiles: Avoid re-selecting agents each time
  3. Local Plugins: Keep frequently-used custom templates as plugins
  4. Selective Updates: Use agen update instead of full re-init

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text: Issue Solution IDE not detected Use --ide flag explicitly Templates not found Check agen list for available templates Update conflicts Use --force or resolve manually Plugin not working Check agen plugin info <name>

docs.title: Reset Configuration
docs.text:
# Reset global config
agen config reset

# Remove all profiles
rm -rf ~/.config/agen/profiles/

# Remove all plugins
rm -rf ~/.config/agen/plugins/

docs.title: Agent Catalog
docs.text: AGEN includes 20 specialist agents, each with a unique persona, skill set, and behavioral patterns optimized for specific development tasks.

docs.title: How Agents Work
docs.text:
Each agent is defined as a Markdown file with YAML frontmatter containing:

  • name: Unique identifier
  • description: When to use this agent
  • skills: List of skills the agent uses
  • tools: Tools the agent can invoke
  • model: AI model configuration

docs.title: Frontend Specialist
docs.text:
Property Value ID frontend-specialist Skills clean-code, nextjs-react-expert, web-design-guidelines, tailwind-patterns, frontend-design, lint-and-validate Tools Read, Grep, Glob, Bash, Edit, Write

Senior Frontend Architect who builds maintainable React/Next.js systems with performance-first mindset. Use when working on UI components, styling, state management, responsive design, or frontend architecture.

Triggers: component, react, vue, ui, ux, css, tailwind, responsive

docs.title: Selecting Agents During Init
docs.text:
# Install specific agents
agen init --agents frontend-specialist,backend-specialist,test-engineer

# Use the interactive wizard to select agents
agen init

docs.title: Agent Files Location
docs.text:
After installation, agents are located at:

  • Antigravity: .agent/agents/<agent-name>.md
  • Cursor: Concatenated into .cursorrules
  • Windsurf: Concatenated into .windsurfrules
  • Zed: Copied to .zed/prompts/

docs.title: AI Features
docs.text: AGEN includes AI-powered features that analyze your project and provide intelligent suggestions for agent selection and configuration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
AI features include:

Feature Purpose Suggest Analyze project and recommend agents Explain Get detailed explanation of agents/skills Compose Create custom agents from description

docs.title: Automatic Suggestions
docs.text:
agen ai suggest

AGEN analyzes your project to recommend appropriate agents.

docs.title: What Gets Analyzed
docs.text: Factor Detection Project Type Web, mobile, backend, CLI, library Languages JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Go, etc. Frameworks React, Next.js, Express, Django, etc. Testing Has tests directory or test files Docker Has Dockerfile or docker-compose CI/CD Has .github/workflows, .gitlab-ci, etc. Dependencies Parses package.json, go.mod, etc.

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
🔍 Analyzing project...

📊 Project Analysis
───────────────────
Type:       Web Application
Languages:  TypeScript, JavaScript
Frameworks: Next.js, React
Has Tests:  Yes
Has Docker: Yes
Has CI:     Yes

🎯 Recommended Agents
─────────────────────
Score  Agent                Reason
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

docs.title: Explain Skills
docs.text: agen ai explain --skill clean-code

docs.title: Create Custom Agents
docs.text:
agen ai compose my-reviewer \
  --description "Code reviewer focused on React and accessibility" \
  --base frontend-specialist,test-engineer

docs.title: What Gets Generated
docs.text:
AGEN creates a custom agent by:

  1. Analyzing the description for key capabilities
  2. Selecting relevant skills from base agents
  3. Generating a custom system prompt
  4. Creating a new agent markdown file

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
🎨 Composing custom agent: my-reviewer
────────────────────────────────────────

Based on analysis of:
  • Description: "Code reviewer focused on React and accessibility"
  • Base agents: frontend-specialist, test-engineer

📝 Generated Agent
──────────────────
Name: my-reviewer
Skills: clean-code, nextjs-react-expert, testing-patterns, 
        frontend-design, code-review-checklist

💾 Saved to: .agent/agents/my-reviewer.md

🔧 Customize by editing the generated file.

docs.title: Suggestion Scoring
docs.text:
Agents are scored 0.0 to 1.0 based on:

Factor Weight Example Framework Match High React project → frontend-specialist Language Match Medium Python → python-patterns skill Project Type Medium API → backend-specialist Best Practice Low All projects → security-auditor

docs.title: Score Interpretation
docs.text: Score Meaning 0.90+ Highly recommended, strong match 0.70-0.89 Recommended, good match 0.50-0.69 Consider, moderate match Below 0.50 Optional, weak match

docs.title: Package.json Analysis
docs.text:
For JavaScript/TypeScript projects:

{
  "dependencies": {
    "react": "18.x",      // → frontend-specialist
    "next": "14.x",       // → nextjs-react-expert skill
    "express": "4.x",     // → backend-specialist
    "jest": "29.x"        // → test-engineer
  }
}

docs.title: Go.mod Analysis
docs.text:
For Go projects:

module myproject

require (
    github.com/gin-gonic/gin  // → backend-specialist
    github.com/lib/pq         // → database-architect
)

docs.title: File Pattern Detection
docs.text: Pattern Detection *.test.ts, *.spec.js Testing → test-engineer Dockerfile Docker → devops-engineer .github/workflows/ CI/CD → devops-engineer *.sql, migrations/ Database → database-architect *.md, docs/ Documentation → documentation-writer

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Run on New Projects: Use agen ai suggest when starting
  2. Review Suggestions: Don't blindly accept all suggestions
  3. Iterate: Re-run after major dependency changes
  4. Customize Compositions: Edit generated custom agents
  5. Combine with Profiles: Save good configurations as profiles

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: AGEN is designed as a modular, stateless CLI tool that acts as a bridge between high-quality AI prompts and your development environment.

docs.title: High-Level Overview
docs.text:
graph TD
    User[User] --> CLI[CLI Layer]
    CLI --> Detector[IDE Detector]
    CLI --> Templates[Template Engine]
    CLI --> TUI[TUI Wizard]
    CLI --> AI[AI Suggester]

    Detector -->|Identifies| Adapter[IDE Adapter]

    Adapter -->|Format specific| Output[Project Files]
    Templates -->|Provides content| Adapter

    subgraph "IDE Adapters"
        Antigravity
        Cursor
        Windsurf
        Zed
    end

    subgraph "Extended Features"
        Plugins[Plugin Manager]
        Team[Team Config]
        Verify[Verification]
        Updater[Self-Update]
    end

docs.title: 1. CLI Layer (internal/cli)
docs.text:
Built with Cobra, this layer handles argument parsing, flag management, and user interaction.

File Purpose root.go Base command, global flags, subcommand registration init.go agen init - template installation list.go agen list - template listing status.go agen status - installation status health.go agen health - project health dashboard search.go agen search - fuzzy search update.go agen update - template updates upgrade.go agen upgrade - binary self-update verify.go agen verify - verification runner profile.go agen profile - profile management team.go agen team - team collaboration plugin.go agen plugin - plugin management ai.go agen ai - AI features create.go agen create - custom templates remote.go agen remote - remote sources

docs.title: 2. IDE Abstraction (internal/ide)
docs.text:
AGEN uses an Adapter pattern to support multiple IDEs. Each IDE implementation satisfies the Adapter interface:

type Adapter interface {
    Name() string
    Detect(projectPath string) bool
    Install(tmpl *Templates, opts InstallOptions) error
    Update(tmpl *Templates, opts UpdateOptions) (*UpdateChanges, error)
    GetRulesPath() string
}
Adapter File Target AntigravityAdapter antigravity.go .agent/ directory CursorAdapter cursor.go .cursorrules file WindsurfAdapter windsurf.go .windsurfrules file ZedAdapter zed.go .zed/prompts/

Detection (detector.go): - Scans for IDE-specific marker files - Returns appropriate adapter or nil - Priority: Cursor > Windsurf > Zed > Antigravity

docs.title: 3. Template Engine (internal/templates)
docs.text:
Templates are embedded directly into the Go binary using go:embed.

File Purpose embedded.go Template loading, parsing, installation data/agents/*.md 20 agent templates data/skills/*/SKILL.md 36 skill templates data/workflows/*.md 8 workflow templates

Key Operations: - LoadEmbedded(): Loads all templates from embedded FS - Filter(): Selects specific agents/skills - InstallTo(): Writes templates to target directory

Template Format: 

---
name: agent-name
description: Brief description
skills: skill1, skill2
tools: Read, Write, Edit
---

# Agent Content

System prompt and behavioral instructions...

docs.title: 4. TUI Wizard (internal/tui)
docs.text:
Interactive terminal UI built with Bubble Tea.

Component Purpose wizard.go Main wizard flow model.go TUI state model views.go Screen renderers styles.go Lipgloss styling

Wizard Steps: 1. IDE Selection (if not detected) 2. Agent Selection (multi-select) 3. Skill Selection (multi-select) 4. Confirmation

docs.title: 5. AI Suggester (internal/ai)
docs.text:
Analyzes projects and provides intelligent recommendations.

type Suggester struct {
    templates *Templates
}

func (s *Suggester) Suggest(projectDir string) ([]Suggestion, error)
func (s *Suggester) ExplainSkill(name string) (string, error)
func (s *Suggester) Compose(name, description string, baseAgents []string) (*ComposedAgent, error)

Analysis Factors: - Package manager files (package.json, go.mod, requirements.txt) - Framework detection - Directory structure - Configuration files

docs.title: 6. Verification Runner (internal/verify)
docs.text:
Runs automated checks on projects.

type Runner struct {
    projectPath string
    options     RunnerOptions
}

func (r *Runner) RunSecurity() Result    // Security scanning
func (r *Runner) RunLint() Result        // Code quality
func (r *Runner) RunUX() Result          // Accessibility/UX
func (r *Runner) RunSEO() Result         // SEO checks

docs.title: 7. Plugin Manager (internal/plugin)
docs.text:
Manages plugin installation and lifecycle.

type Manager struct {
    pluginDir string
    registry  *Registry
}

func (m *Manager) Install(source string) (*Plugin, error)
func (m *Manager) Uninstall(name string) error
func (m *Manager) List() []*Plugin
func (m *Manager) Create(name, pluginType string) (string, error)

Supported Sources: - GitHub repositories - Local file paths - HTTP/HTTPS URLs

docs.title: 8. Team Configuration (internal/team)
docs.text:
Handles shared team configurations.

type TeamConfig struct {
    Name           string            `json:"name"`
    RequiredAgents []string          `json:"required_agents"`
    RequiredSkills []string          `json:"required_skills"`
    LockedVersions map[string]string `json:"locked_versions"`
    Settings       TeamSettings      `json:"settings"`
}

func (tc *TeamConfig) Sync(projectDir string) (*SyncResult, error)
func (tc *TeamConfig) Validate(projectDir string) (*ValidationResult, error)

docs.title: 9. Global Configuration (internal/config)
docs.text:
Manages user preferences and global settings.

type Config struct {
    AnalyticsEnabled bool   `json:"analytics_enabled"`
    AutoCheckUpdates bool   `json:"auto_check_updates"`
    DefaultIDE       string `json:"default_ide"`
    CacheDir         string `json:"cache_dir"`
}

Storage Locations: - Linux: ~/.config/agen/config.json - macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/agen/config.json - Windows: %APPDATA%\agen\config.json

docs.title: 10. Self-Updater (internal/updater)
docs.text:
Handles binary self-updates from GitHub releases.

type Updater struct {
    currentVersion string
    githubRepo     string
}

func (u *Updater) Check() (*Release, error)
func (u *Updater) Update(release *Release) error

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text: Directory Purpose cmd/agen Main entry point internal/cli Command implementations (18 files) internal/ide IDE adapters (5 files) internal/templates Template engine + embedded data internal/templates/data 64 template files internal/tui Terminal UI wizard internal/ai AI suggester internal/verify Verification runner internal/plugin Plugin manager internal/team Team configuration internal/config Global configuration internal/updater Self-update logic docs MkDocs documentation

docs.title: Initialization Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant CLI
    participant Detector
    participant TUI
    participant Templates
    participant Adapter

    User->>CLI: agen init
    CLI->>Detector: Detect IDE
    alt IDE detected
        Detector-->>CLI: Adapter
    else No IDE
        CLI->>TUI: Launch wizard
        TUI-->>CLI: User selections
    end
    CLI->>Templates: Load & filter
    Templates-->>CLI: Selected templates
    CLI->>Adapter: Install templates
    Adapter-->>User: Files created

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text: Package Purpose github.com/spf13/cobra CLI framework github.com/charmbracelet/bubbletea TUI framework github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss Terminal styling github.com/fatih/color Colored output github.com/sahilm/fuzzy Fuzzy search gopkg.in/yaml.v3 YAML parsing github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify File watching

docs.title: Design Principles
docs.text:
1. Stateless: No daemon, no server, just a CLI tool
  2. Offline-First: Embedded templates work without network
  3. IDE-Agnostic: Adapter pattern for multiple IDEs
  4. Zero Config: Works out-of-box with sensible defaults
  5. Extensible: Plugin system for custom extensions

docs.title: Command Reference
docs.text: Comprehensive guide to all agen CLI commands, flags, and usage examples.

docs.title: Global Flags
docs.text:
These flags are available for all commands:

Flag Description -v, --verbose Enable verbose output for debugging --no-color Disable colored output (useful for scripts) --version Show version information -h, --help Show help for any command

docs.title: agen init
docs.text:
Initialize agent templates in the current or specified project directory. This is the main bootstrapping command.

Usage: 

agen init [path] [flags]

Flags:

Flag Description -i, --ide string Force specific IDE (antigravity, cursor, windsurf, zed) -a, --agents strings Comma-separated list of agents to install -s, --skills strings Comma-separated list of skills to install -f, --force Overwrite existing files without prompting --dry-run Show what would be done without making changes --no-wizard Skip the interactive TUI wizard

Examples: 

# Interactive mode (wizard)
agen init

# Quick setup for a specific stack
agen init --ide cursor --agents frontend,backend --skills react,node --force

# Just verify what would happen
agen init --dry-run

# Initialize a specific directory
agen init /path/to/project --ide antigravity

docs.title: agen list
docs.text:
List all available templates that can be installed.

Usage: 

agen list [flags]

Flags:

Flag Description -a, --agents Only list agents -s, --skills Only list skills -w, --workflows Only list workflows --json Output in JSON format

Examples: 

# List everything
agen list

# List only agents
agen list --agents

# Export as JSON for scripting
agen list --json > templates.json

docs.title: agen status
docs.text:
Check the installation status of AGEN in the current directory.

Usage: 

agen status

Output includes: - Detected IDE - Installed agents - Installed skills - Configuration health

docs.title: agen health
docs.text:
Analyze the current project's configuration health with recommendations.

Usage: 

agen health [path]

Checks Performed: - IDE Config: Validates .agent/, .cursorrules, etc. - Version Status: Checks if templates are up-to-date - Local Modifications: Detects customized templates - Recommendations: Suggests agents based on project type

Example: 

agen health
# Shows health score and recommendations

docs.title: agen search
docs.text:
Perform a fuzzy search across all agents, skills, and workflows.

Usage: 

agen search <query> [flags]

Flags:

Flag Description -n, --limit int Maximum number of results (default 10)

Examples: 

agen search security    # Finds security-auditor, penetration-tester
agen search react       # Finds frontend-specialist, react-related skills
agen search test -n 20  # Show up to 20 results

docs.title: agen update
docs.text:
Update installed templates to the latest version from the binary.

Usage: 

agen update [flags]

Flags:

Flag Description -f, --force Overwrite local modifications --dry-run Show what files would be updated

Smart Updates: AGEN respects local changes. Modified files are skipped unless --force is used.

docs.title: agen upgrade
docs.text:
Upgrade the agen binary itself to the latest version.

Usage: 

agen upgrade

Downloads and installs the latest release from GitHub.

docs.title: agen profile
docs.text:
Manage configuration profiles for reuse across projects.

Subcommands:

Command Description save <name> Save current config as a profile load <name> Apply a saved profile list List all saved profiles delete <name> Delete a saved profile export <name> Export profile as JSON (stdout) import <file> Import profile from JSON file

Examples: 

# Save current configuration
agen profile save frontend-stack

# Load profile into new project
agen profile load frontend-stack

# Export for sharing
agen profile export frontend-stack > frontend.json

# Import shared profile
agen profile import frontend.json

See Profiles for detailed documentation.

docs.title: agen team
docs.text:
Manage team collaboration and shared configurations.

Subcommands:

Command Description init <name> Initialize team configuration require <type> <name> Add required agent/skill remove <type> <name> Remove requirement lock <name> <version> Lock template version unlock <name> Remove version lock sync Sync project with team config validate Validate against team requirements config <key> <value> Modify team settings

Examples: 

# Initialize team config
agen team init my-team

# Require security-auditor for all team members
agen team require agent security-auditor

# Sync project with team requirements
agen team sync

# Validate project meets team requirements
agen team validate --strict

See Team Collaboration for detailed documentation.

docs.title: agen plugin
docs.text:
Manage AGEN plugins.

Subcommands:

Command Description install <source> Install plugin from GitHub/URL/path uninstall <name> Remove installed plugin list List installed plugins info <name> Show plugin details create <name> Create new plugin project

Examples: 

# Install from GitHub
agen plugin install github.com/user/agen-security-pack

# Install from local path
agen plugin install /path/to/my-plugin

# Create new plugin
agen plugin create my-plugin --type bundle

See Plugin System for detailed documentation.

docs.title: agen ai
docs.text:
AI-powered features for intelligent suggestions.

Subcommands:

Command Description suggest Analyze project and recommend agents explain <name> Get detailed explanation of agent/skill compose <name> Create custom agent from description

Examples: 

# Get agent suggestions for current project
agen ai suggest

# Learn about an agent
agen ai explain frontend-specialist

# Create a custom agent
agen ai compose my-reviewer --description "React code reviewer"

See AI Features for detailed documentation.

docs.title: agen verify
docs.text:
Run verification checks on your project.

Usage: 

agen verify [flags]

Flags:

Flag Description --verbose Show detailed output --security Only run security checks --lint Only run lint checks

Example: 

agen verify
# Runs security, lint, UX, and SEO checks

See Verification for detailed documentation.

docs.title: agen create
docs.text:
Create custom agents or skills.

Usage: 

agen create <type> <name>

Types: agent, skill, workflow

Example: 

agen create agent my-custom-agent
# Creates .agent/agents/my-custom-agent.md

docs.title: agen remote
docs.text:
Manage remote template sources.

Subcommands:

Command Description add <name> <url> Add remote source remove <name> Remove remote source list List configured remotes fetch Fetch templates from remotes

docs.title: agen config
docs.text:
Manage global AGEN configuration.

Subcommands:

Command Description get <key> Get config value set <key> <value> Set config value list Show all config reset Reset to defaults

Example: 

agen config set default_ide cursor
agen config set auto_check_updates false

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text: Code Meaning 0 Success 1 General error 2 Configuration error 3 Template not found 4 IDE not detected 5 Validation failed

docs.title: Shell Completion
docs.text:
Generate shell completion scripts:

# Bash
agen completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/agen

# Zsh
agen completion zsh > "${fpath[1]}/_agen"

# Fish
agen completion fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/agen.fish

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: AGEN is designed to be "zero-config" for most users, deriving its context from your project structure. However, there are ways to customize its behavior.

docs.title: Global Configuration
docs.text:
AGEN stores global data in your system's user config directory:

  • Linux: ~/.config/agen/
  • macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/agen/
  • Windows: %APPDATA%\agen\

docs.title: Profiles
docs.text: Saved profiles are stored in the profiles/ subdirectory as JSON files. You can manually edit these if needed, though using the agen profile command is recommended.

docs.title: Project Configuration
docs.text: Once initialized, AGEN's configuration lives inside your project.

docs.title: Antigravity (.agent/)
docs.text: This is the most granular configuration. You can directly edit any file in .agent/agents/ or .agent/skills/. - Rules: .agent/rules/ contains global rules applied to all agents.

docs.title: Cursor (.cursorrules)
docs.text: This is a single generated file. Warning: If you edit this file manually, agen update might overwrite your changes unless you are careful. - Tip: AGEN adds comments to sections. Try to keep your custom rules outside the managed blocks if possible, or use the agen update conflict resolution prompts.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description AGEN_NO_COLOR Set to true to disable colored output. AGEN_DEBUG Set to true to enable verbose debug logging (equivalent to --verbose).

docs.title: Custom Templates (Advanced)
docs.text:
You can maintain your own library of templates that override the built-in ones.

  1. Create ~/.agen-templates/ directory.
  2. Create agents/ and skills/ subdirectories.
  3. Add your Markdown files there.

AGEN will prioritize these local templates over the embedded ones during init and update.

docs.title: Contributing to AGEN
docs.text: We love contributions! This guide covers everything you need to know to contribute to AGEN.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Go 1.22+ - Install Go
  • Git - For version control
  • Make (optional) - For development shortcuts

docs.title: Clone and Build
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/eshanized/agen.git
cd agen

# Install dependencies
go mod download

# Build the binary
go build -o agen ./cmd/agen

# Or use Make
make build

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
./agen --version
./agen list

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
agen/
├── cmd/agen/              # Entry point
│   └── main.go
├── internal/              # Internal packages
│   ├── cli/              # CLI commands (18 files)
│   ├── ide/              # IDE adapters
│   ├── templates/        # Template engine
│   │   └── data/         # Embedded templates
│   ├── tui/              # Terminal UI
│   ├── ai/               # AI features
│   ├── verify/           # Verification
│   ├── plugin/           # Plugin manager
│   ├── team/             # Team config
│   ├── config/           # Global config
│   └── updater/          # Self-update
├── docs/                  # Documentation
├── templates/            # Example templates
└── Makefile

docs.title: Adding New Templates
docs.text: Templates are the core content of AGEN.

docs.title: Adding an Agent
docs.text:
1. Create a new file in internal/templates/data/agents/:
touch internal/templates/data/agents/my-new-agent.md
  1. Add YAML frontmatter and content:
---
name: my-new-agent
description: Description of what this agent does and when to use it
tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash, Edit, Write
skills: clean-code, relevant-skill
---

# My New Agent

You are a specialized agent that...

## Your Expertise

...

## Guidelines

...
  1. Rebuild the binary to embed the new template:
go build -o agen ./cmd/agen

docs.title: Adding a Skill
docs.text:
1. Create a skill directory:
mkdir -p internal/templates/data/skills/my-new-skill
touch internal/templates/data/skills/my-new-skill/SKILL.md
  1. Add skill content:
---
name: my-new-skill
description: Brief description of the skill
version: 1.0
---

# My New Skill Title

## Purpose

...

## Guidelines

...
  1. Optionally add verification scripts:
mkdir internal/templates/data/skills/my-new-skill/scripts
touch internal/templates/data/skills/my-new-skill/scripts/my_checker.py

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
Commands are in internal/cli/. Each command follows this pattern:

// internal/cli/mycommand.go
package cli

import (
    "fmt"
    "github.com/spf13/cobra"
)

var myCmd = &cobra.Command{
    Use:   "mycommand <args>",
    Short: "Short description",
    Long:  `Longer description with examples.`,
    Args:  cobra.ExactArgs(1),
    RunE:  runMyCommand,
}

func init() {
    // Register with root command
    rootCmd.AddCommand(myCmd)

    // Add flags
    myCmd.Flags().BoolP("force", "f", false, "force operation")
}

func runMyCommand(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
    force, _ := cmd.Flags().GetBool("force")

    // Command logic here

    return nil
}

docs.title: Registering Commands
docs.text: Commands are automatically registered via their init() functions. Just create the file and add the command to rootCmd.

docs.title: Adapter Interface
docs.text:
Implement the Adapter interface in internal/ide/:

// internal/ide/myide.go
package ide

import (
    "github.com/eshanized/agen/internal/templates"
)

type MyIDEAdapter struct{}

func (a *MyIDEAdapter) Name() string {
    return "MyIDE"
}

func (a *MyIDEAdapter) Detect(projectPath string) bool {
    // Check for IDE-specific files
    // Return true if this IDE is detected
}

func (a *MyIDEAdapter) Install(tmpl *templates.Templates, opts InstallOptions) error {
    // Write templates in IDE-specific format
}

func (a *MyIDEAdapter) Update(tmpl *templates.Templates, opts UpdateOptions) (*UpdateChanges, error) {
    // Handle updates with conflict detection
}

func (a *MyIDEAdapter) GetRulesPath() string {
    return ".myide/rules"
}

docs.title: Registering Adapters
docs.text:
Add to internal/ide/detector.go:

func init() {
    adapters["myide"] = &MyIDEAdapter{}
}

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
# Run all tests
go test ./...

# Run with verbose output
go test -v ./...

# Run specific package tests
go test -v ./internal/cli/...

# Run with coverage
go test -cover ./...

# Generate coverage report
go test -coverprofile=coverage.out ./...
go tool cover -html=coverage.out

# Or use Make
make test

docs.title: Formatting
docs.text:
# Format all code
go fmt ./...

# Or use Make
make fmt

docs.title: Linting
docs.text:
# Run linter (install golangci-lint first)
golangci-lint run

# Or use Make
make lint

docs.title: Guidelines
docs.text:
1. Clear names: Use descriptive variable and function names
  2. Comments: Add comments for non-obvious logic
  3. Error handling: Always handle errors, don't ignore them
  4. Small functions: Keep functions focused and small
  5. Tests: Add tests for new functionality

docs.title: Adding Documentation
docs.text:
Docs are in docs/ and use MkDocs.

  1. Create or edit markdown files in docs/
  2. Update mkdocs.yml navigation if adding new pages
  3. Preview locally:
pip install mkdocs-material pymdown-extensions
mkdocs serve

docs.title: Building Docs
docs.text: mkdocs build

docs.title: Before Submitting
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Create a branch: git checkout -b feature/my-feature
  3. Make changes and commit with clear messages
  4. Run tests: go test ./...
  5. Run linter: golangci-lint run
  6. Update docs if necessary

docs.title: Commit Messages
docs.text:
Use clear, descriptive commit messages:

feat: add new xyz command

- Implements the xyz functionality
- Adds tests for xyz
- Updates documentation

Prefixes: - feat: New feature - fix: Bug fix - docs: Documentation only - refactor: Code refactoring - test: Adding tests - chore: Maintenance tasks

docs.title: Submitting
docs.text:
1. Push your branch
  2. Open a Pull Request
  3. Fill out the PR template
  4. Wait for review

docs.title: Release Process
docs.text: Releases are automated via GoReleaser.

docs.title: Creating a Release
docs.text:
# Tag a new version
git tag v1.2.3
git push origin v1.2.3

GitHub Actions automatically: 1. Builds for all platforms 2. Creates GitHub release 3. Updates Homebrew tap 4. Updates Scoop bucket 5. Updates AUR package

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• GitHub Issues: Report bugs or request features
  • Discussions: Ask questions or share ideas
  • Email: eshanized@proton.me

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: Please be respectful and constructive. We welcome contributors of all backgrounds and experience levels.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Once you have installed AGEN, you are ready to start using it in your projects.

docs.title: Initialize a Project
docs.text:
Navigate to your project directory and run:

cd my-project
agen init

AGEN will: 1. Detect your IDE: It looks for .cursorrules, .windsurfrules, .zed/, or .agent/ folders. 2. Launch Wizard: If no IDE is configured, it will ask you to choose one and select agents/skills. 3. Install Templates: It will copy the necessary configuration files to your project.

docs.title: Non-Interactive Mode
docs.text:
You can skip the wizard by passing flags:

# Force usage of Cursor IDE
agen init --ide cursor

# Install specific agents and skills
agen init --agents frontend,backend --skills docker

docs.title: List Available Templates
docs.text:
To see what agents and skills are available:

agen list

This will show: - Agents: Specialist personalities (e.g., Frontend, Backend, DevOps) - Skills: Reuseable capabilities (e.g., Docker, SQL, Git) - Workflows: Common task automations

docs.title: Check Project Health
docs.text:
Run agen health to check if your project's agent configuration is healthy:

agen health

This checks for: - Missing dependencies - Broken links - Syntax errors in configuration files

docs.title: IDE Support
docs.text: AGEN supports 12 IDEs and AI coding tools by adapting its internal template format to the specific requirements of each environment.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: IDE/Tool Config File Auto-detection Antigravity .agent/ folder ✅ .agent/ directory Cursor .cursorrules ✅ .cursorrules file Windsurf .windsurfrules ✅ .windsurfrules file Cline .clinerules ✅ .clinerules file Continue .continue/ ✅ .continue/ directory Zed .zed/ folder ✅ .zed/ directory JetBrains .idea/ ✅ .idea/ directory Neovim .nvim/ ✅ .nvim/ or .nvim.lua Emacs .dir-locals.el ✅ .dir-locals.el file Aider .aider.conf.yml ✅ .aider.conf.yml Claude Code CLAUDE.md ✅ CLAUDE.md file Copilot Workspace .github/copilot-instructions.md ✅ .github/

docs.title: Cursor
docs.text:
Cursor uses a single rules file to define AI behavior.

  • Detection: Checks for .cursorrules
  • Format: Consolidated .cursorrules file with agents, skills, and workflows
  • Install: agen init --ide cursor

docs.title: Windsurf
docs.text:
Windsurf follows a similar pattern to Cursor.

  • Detection: Checks for .windsurfrules
  • Format: Single .windsurfrules file containing all context
  • Install: agen init --ide windsurf

docs.title: Cline
docs.text:
Cline (formerly Roo-Cline) is a popular VS Code AI coding extension.

  • Detection: Checks for .clinerules or .cline/
  • Format: Single .clinerules file with project rules
  • Install: agen init --ide cline
  • Website: github.com/cline/cline

docs.title: Continue
docs.text:
Continue is an open-source AI coding assistant for VS Code.

  • Detection: Checks for .continue/ or .continuerules
  • Format: .continue/config.json + .continuerules
  • Install: agen init --ide continue
  • Website: continue.dev

docs.title: Antigravity
docs.text:
This is the native format for AGEN (Google Gemini/Claude).

  • Detection: Checks for .agent/ directory or GEMINI.md
  • Structure: 
    .agent/
├── agents/       # Agent personas (.md)
├── skills/       # Reusable skills (folders with SKILL.md)
├── workflows/    # Workflows (.md)
└── rules/        # Global rules
  • Features: Full support for all AGEN features

docs.title: Zed
docs.text:
Zed uses a folder-based approach for prompts and context.

  • Detection: Checks for .zed/ directory
  • Structure: 
    .zed/
├── settings.json   # Configuration
└── prompts/        # Context files
  • Install: agen init --ide zed

docs.title: JetBrains
docs.text:
Supports IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm, WebStorm, GoLand, and other JetBrains IDEs.

  • Detection: Checks for .idea/ directory
  • Format: .idea/ai-assistant.xml + .jbrules.md
  • Install: agen init --ide jetbrains
  • Plugins: Works with JetBrains AI Assistant

docs.title: Neovim
docs.text:
Supports various Neovim AI plugins.

  • Detection: Checks for .nvim/ or .nvim.lua
  • Format: .nvim/ai-rules.md + .nvim.lua
  • Install: agen init --ide neovim
  • Plugins: codecompanion.nvim, avante.nvim, ChatGPT.nvim

docs.title: Emacs
docs.text:
Supports Emacs AI plugins like gptel and ellama.

  • Detection: Checks for .dir-locals.el
  • Format: .emacs-project/ai-context.md + .dir-locals.el
  • Install: agen init --ide emacs
  • Plugins: gptel, ellama, copilot.el

docs.title: Aider
docs.text:
Aider is a command-line AI pair programming tool.

  • Detection: Checks for .aider.conf.yml or .aider/
  • Format: .aider.conf.yml + .aider-context.md
  • Install: agen init --ide aider
  • Website: aider.chat

docs.title: Claude Code
docs.text:
Anthropic's Claude Code uses a similar format to Antigravity.

  • Detection: Checks for CLAUDE.md
  • Format: Single CLAUDE.md file in project root
  • Install: agen init --ide claudecode

docs.title: GitHub Copilot Workspace
docs.text:
GitHub Copilot can use custom instructions per repository.

  • Detection: Checks for .github/copilot-instructions.md
  • Format: .github/copilot-instructions.md
  • Install: agen init --ide copilotworkspace
  • Docs: GitHub Copilot Custom Instructions

docs.title: Specifying an IDE
docs.text:
You can explicitly specify which IDE format to use:

# Auto-detect (default)
agen init

# Explicit IDE selection
agen init --ide cursor
agen init --ide continue
agen init --ide jetbrains

docs.title: Multiple IDEs
docs.text:
AGEN can generate configurations for multiple IDEs simultaneously:

agen init --ide cursor --ide continue --ide copilotworkspace

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: AGEN supports macOS, Linux, and Windows. Choose the method that works best for you.

docs.title: macOS / Linux (Homebrew)
docs.text:
If you use Homebrew, you can install from our tap:

brew install eshanized/tap/agen

docs.title: Windows (Scoop)
docs.text:
For Windows users using Scoop:

scoop bucket add eshanized https://github.com/eshanized/scoop-bucket
scoop install agen

docs.title: Arch Linux (AUR)
docs.text:
Arch Linux users can install from the AUR:

yay -S agen-bin

docs.title: Debian / Ubuntu
docs.text:
Download the latest .deb package from GitHub Releases and install:

sudo dpkg -i agen_*.deb

docs.title: Binary Download
docs.text:
You can download pre-compiled binaries for your platform from the Releases Page.

  1. Download the archive for your OS/Arch.
  2. Extract the agen binary.
  3. Move it to a directory in your $PATH (e.g., /usr/local/bin).

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text:
Requirements: Go 1.22+

git clone https://github.com/eshanized/agen.git
cd agen
go build -o agen ./cmd/agen

docs.title: Plugin System
docs.text: AGEN supports plugins to extend its functionality with custom agents, skills, and workflows.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Plugins can be installed from:

  • GitHub: github.com/user/repo
  • Local Path: /path/to/plugin
  • URL: https://example.com/plugin.zip

docs.title: From GitHub
docs.text:
# Install from GitHub repository
agen plugin install github.com/username/agen-security-pack

docs.title: From Local Path
docs.text:
# Install from local directory
agen plugin install /path/to/my-plugin

docs.title: From URL
docs.text:
# Install from zip URL
agen plugin install https://example.com/plugins/my-plugin.zip

docs.title: List Installed Plugins
docs.text:
agen plugin list

Output: 

📦 Installed Plugins

NAME                    VERSION   TYPE      AGENTS  SKILLS
security-pack           1.2.0     bundle    3       5
my-custom-agent         1.0.0     agent     1       0
react-patterns          2.1.0     skill     0       4

docs.title: Uninstall Plugin
docs.text: agen plugin uninstall security-pack

docs.title: Get Plugin Info
docs.text: agen plugin info security-pack

docs.title: Plugin Structure
docs.text:
my-plugin/
├── plugin.json          # Plugin manifest (optional but recommended)
├── agents/              # Custom agents
│   └── my-agent.md
├── skills/              # Custom skills
│   └── my-skill/
│       └── SKILL.md
└── workflows/           # Custom workflows
    └── my-workflow.md

docs.title: Plugin Manifest (plugin.json)
docs.text:
{
  "name": "my-plugin",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "My custom AGEN plugin",
  "author": "Your Name",
  "type": "bundle",
  "agents": ["my-agent"],
  "skills": ["my-skill"],
  "workflows": ["my-workflow"],
  "metadata": {
    "homepage": "https://github.com/user/my-plugin",
    "license": "MIT"
  }
}

docs.title: Plugin Types
docs.text: Type Description agent Contains only agents skill Contains only skills workflow Contains only workflows bundle Contains multiple types

docs.title: Creating a Plugin Project
docs.text:
Use the CLI to scaffold a new plugin:

# Create an agent plugin
agen plugin create my-agent --type agent

# Create a skill plugin
agen plugin create my-skill --type skill

# Create a bundle plugin
agen plugin create my-bundle --type bundle

This creates a starter structure:

my-agent/
├── plugin.json
├── agents/
│   └── my-agent.md
└── README.md

docs.title: Plugin Registry
docs.text:
Plugins are stored in your AGEN config directory:

Platform Location Linux ~/.config/agen/plugins/ macOS ~/Library/Application Support/agen/plugins/ Windows %APPDATA%\agen\plugins\

A registry file (registry.json) tracks installed plugins.

docs.title: GitHub (Recommended)
docs.text:
1. Create a GitHub repository
  2. Add plugin structure and plugin.json
  3. Create releases with semantic versioning
  4. Users install via agen plugin install github.com/user/repo

docs.title: Distribution
docs.text:
You can also distribute plugins as:

  • ZIP archives
  • Tarballs
  • Direct file copies

docs.title: Agent Plugin Example
docs.text:
Create agents/custom-reviewer.md:

---
name: custom-reviewer
description: Code review specialist with custom rules
tools: Read, Grep, Edit
skills: clean-code, code-review-checklist
---

# Custom Code Reviewer

You are a code reviewer following our team's specific standards...

## Review Checklist

- [ ] Variable naming follows team conventions
- [ ] Error handling is comprehensive
- [ ] Tests cover edge cases

docs.title: Skill Plugin Example
docs.text:
Create skills/docker-expert/SKILL.md:

---
name: docker-expert
description: Advanced Docker and containerization patterns
version: 1.0
---

# Docker Expert Skill

## Container Best Practices

- Multi-stage builds for smaller images
- Non-root user execution
- Proper layer caching
- Health checks

## Common Commands

| Command | Purpose |
|---------|---------|
| `docker build` | Build image |
| `docker compose up` | Start services |

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Version Your Plugins: Use semantic versioning
  2. Include README: Document usage and requirements
  3. Test Locally: Use agen plugin install /local/path first
  4. Keep Dependencies Minimal: Plugins should be self-contained
  5. Follow Naming Conventions: Use kebab-case for names

docs.title: Profile Management
docs.text: Profiles allow you to save and reuse agent configurations across projects. Think of them as "presets" for your AI development environment.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
A profile captures:

  • Selected IDE
  • Installed agents
  • Installed skills
  • Installed workflows
  • Timestamp metadata

docs.title: Save Current Configuration
docs.text:
agen profile save frontend-stack

This saves the current project's configuration as a named profile.

docs.title: What Gets Saved
docs.text: The profile captures: - Which IDE format is being used - List of installed agents - List of installed skills - List of installed workflows

docs.title: Apply Profile to Project
docs.text:
agen profile load frontend-stack

This installs all agents and skills from the saved profile.

docs.title: Load with IDE Override
docs.text: agen profile load frontend-stack --ide cursor

docs.title: View All Profiles
docs.text:
agen profile list

Output: 

📋 Saved Profiles

NAME              IDE           AGENTS  SKILLS  CREATED
frontend-stack    antigravity   4       8       2026-01-15
backend-api       cursor        3       5       2026-01-10
fullstack         antigravity   6       12      2026-01-05
security-audit    windsurf      2       4       2026-01-01

docs.title: Remove a Profile
docs.text: agen profile delete old-profile

docs.title: Export Profile to JSON
docs.text:
# Export to stdout
agen profile export frontend-stack

# Export to file
agen profile export frontend-stack > frontend-stack.json

docs.title: Import Profile from JSON
docs.text: agen profile import frontend-stack.json

docs.title: Profile File Format
docs.text:
Profiles are stored as JSON files:

{
  "name": "frontend-stack",
  "ide": "antigravity",
  "agents": [
    "frontend-specialist",
    "test-engineer",
    "performance-optimizer",
    "seo-specialist"
  ],
  "skills": [
    "clean-code",
    "nextjs-react-expert",
    "tailwind-patterns",
    "testing-patterns",
    "performance-profiling",
    "seo-fundamentals"
  ],
  "workflows": [
    "orchestrate",
    "deploy"
  ],
  "created_at": "2026-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "modified_at": "2026-01-20T14:15:00Z"
}

docs.title: Profile Storage Location
docs.text:
Profiles are stored in your AGEN config directory:

Platform Location Linux ~/.config/agen/profiles/ macOS ~/Library/Application Support/agen/profiles/ Windows %APPDATA%\agen\profiles\

Each profile is saved as <name>.json.

docs.title: Frontend Development
docs.text:
agen init --agents frontend-specialist,test-engineer,seo-specialist \
          --skills clean-code,nextjs-react-expert,tailwind-patterns
agen profile save frontend-dev

docs.title: Backend API
docs.text:
agen init --agents backend-specialist,security-auditor,database-architect \
          --skills api-patterns,nodejs-best-practices,database-design
agen profile save backend-api

docs.title: Full Stack
docs.text:
agen init --agents frontend-specialist,backend-specialist,devops-engineer,test-engineer \
          --skills clean-code,nextjs-react-expert,api-patterns,deployment-procedures
agen profile save fullstack

docs.title: Security Audit
docs.text:
agen init --agents security-auditor,penetration-tester \
          --skills vulnerability-scanner,red-team-tactics
agen profile save security

docs.title: Mobile Development
docs.text:
agen init --agents mobile-developer,test-engineer,performance-optimizer \
          --skills mobile-design,testing-patterns,performance-profiling
agen profile save mobile

docs.title: Export for Team
docs.text:
# Export profile
agen profile export frontend-stack > frontend-stack.json

# Share the file with team members
# They import with:
agen profile import frontend-stack.json

docs.title: Version Control
docs.text:
You can commit profile JSON files to a repository:

my-team-profiles/
├── frontend.json
├── backend.json
├── fullstack.json
└── security.json

Team members clone and import as needed.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Descriptive Names: Use clear, descriptive profile names
  2. Keep Updated: Recreate profiles when you find better agent combinations
  3. Document Profiles: Note what each profile is intended for
  4. Share With Team: Export and share successful configurations
  5. Project-Specific: Create profiles for different project types

docs.title: Project Files
docs.text: This document describes the internal file structures that AGEN creates and manages.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
After running agen init, AGEN creates configuration files specific to your IDE. The structure varies by IDE:

IDE Primary Files Antigravity .agent/ directory Cursor .cursorrules file Windsurf .windsurfrules file Zed .zed/ directory

docs.title: Antigravity Format (Native)
docs.text: The Antigravity format is AGEN's native format with full feature support.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
.agent/
├── agents/              # Agent persona files
│   ├── frontend-specialist.md
│   ├── backend-specialist.md
│   └── ...
├── skills/              # Skill modules
│   ├── clean-code/
│   │   └── SKILL.md
│   ├── api-patterns/
│   │   ├── SKILL.md
│   │   └── scripts/
│   │       └── api_validator.py
│   └── ...
├── workflows/           # Workflow automations
│   ├── orchestrate.md
│   ├── deploy.md
│   └── ...
├── rules/               # Global rules
│   └── GEMINI.md
└── scripts/             # Shared scripts

docs.title: Agent File Format
docs.text:
---
name: frontend-specialist
description: Senior Frontend Architect who builds maintainable...
tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash, Edit, Write
model: inherit
skills: clean-code, nextjs-react-expert, tailwind-patterns
---

# Senior Frontend Architect

You are a Senior Frontend Architect who...

## Your Philosophy

...

docs.title: Skill File Format
docs.text:
---
name: clean-code
description: Pragmatic coding standards
allowed-tools: Read, Write, Edit
version: 2.0
priority: CRITICAL
---

# Clean Code - Pragmatic AI Coding Standards

## Core Principles

| Principle | Rule |
|-----------|------|
| **SRP** | Single Responsibility |
| **DRY** | Don't Repeat Yourself |
...

docs.title: Workflow File Format
docs.text:
---
description: Coordinate multiple agents for complex tasks
---

# Multi-Agent Orchestration

You are now in **ORCHESTRATION MODE**...

docs.title: Cursor Format
docs.text: Cursor uses a single .cursorrules file.

docs.title: File Location
docs.text:
project-root/
└── .cursorrules

docs.title: File Format
docs.text:
AGEN concatenates all agents and skills into sections:

# AGEN Configuration - Cursor Format
# Generated by AGEN v1.0.0

## Project Context

[Generated project context]

## Agents

### Frontend Specialist

[Agent content...]

### Backend Specialist

[Agent content...]

## Skills

### clean-code

[Skill content...]

## End of AGEN Configuration

docs.title: Windsurf Format
docs.text: Windsurf uses a single .windsurfrules file, similar to Cursor.

docs.title: File Location
docs.text:
project-root/
└── .windsurfrules

docs.title: File Format
docs.text: Same structure as Cursor, adapted for Windsurf.

docs.title: Zed Format
docs.text: Zed uses a folder-based approach.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
.zed/
├── settings.json        # Zed configuration
└── prompts/             # Context files
    ├── agent-context.md
    └── skill-context.md

docs.title: Global Configuration
docs.text: AGEN stores global data in your system's config directory.

docs.title: Location by Platform
docs.text: Platform Path Linux ~/.config/agen/ macOS ~/Library/Application Support/agen/ Windows %APPDATA%\agen\

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
~/.config/agen/
├── config.json          # Global settings
├── profiles/            # Saved profiles
│   ├── frontend.json
│   └── backend.json
└── plugins/             # Installed plugins
    ├── registry.json
    └── my-plugin/

docs.title: config.json
docs.text:
{
  "analytics_enabled": false,
  "auto_check_updates": true,
  "update_channel": "stable",
  "default_ide": "",
  "default_branch": "main",
  "cache_dir": "",
  "cache_ttl_days": 7
}

docs.title: YAML Frontmatter
docs.text:
All template files use YAML frontmatter for metadata:

---
name: agent-name
description: Brief description
skills: skill1, skill2, skill3
tools: Read, Write, Edit
model: inherit
version: 1.0
priority: NORMAL
---

docs.title: Frontmatter Fields
docs.text: Field Type Required Description name string Yes Unique identifier description string Yes What this does skills string/list No Related skills tools string No Available tools model string No AI model setting version string No Template version priority string No Loading priority

docs.title: Team Configuration
docs.text: Team settings are stored in the project root.

docs.title: File Location
docs.text:
project-root/
└── .agen-team.json

docs.title: File Format
docs.text:
{
  "name": "team-name",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "required_agents": ["security-auditor"],
  "required_skills": ["clean-code"],
  "version_locks": {},
  "settings": {
    "enforce_agents": false,
    "enforce_skills": false,
    "allow_plugins": true
  }
}

docs.title: Custom Templates
docs.text: Override built-in templates with local versions.

docs.title: Location
docs.text:
~/.agen-templates/
├── agents/
│   └── my-custom-agent.md
└── skills/
    └── my-custom-skill/
        └── SKILL.md

AGEN checks this directory first before using embedded templates.

docs.title: File Priorities
docs.text:
When loading templates, AGEN checks in order:

  1. Local overrides: ~/.agen-templates/
  2. Installed plugins: ~/.config/agen/plugins/
  3. Embedded templates: Built into the binary

First match wins.

docs.title: Gitignore Recommendations
docs.text:
Add to your .gitignore based on preference:

# Option 1: Track all AGEN config (recommended for teams)
# Nothing to ignore

# Option 2: Ignore AGEN config (personal preference)
.agent/
.cursorrules
.windsurfrules
.zed/

# Always ignore if present
.agen-cache/

For team projects, committing .agen-team.json is recommended.

docs.title: Skill Catalog
docs.text: AGEN includes 36 modular skills that can be mixed and matched across agents. Skills are reusable capabilities that extend agent functionality.

docs.title: How Skills Work
docs.text:
Each skill is a folder containing:

  • SKILL.md - Main skill definition with YAML frontmatter
  • scripts/ (optional) - Verification scripts for the skill

Skills are referenced by agents in their skills: frontmatter field.

docs.title: Selecting Skills During Init
docs.text:
# Install specific skills
agen init --skills clean-code,testing-patterns,api-patterns

# Skills are automatically included with agents
agen init --agents backend-specialist  # Includes api-patterns, etc.

docs.title: Skill Files Location
docs.text:
After installation, skills are located at:

.agent/skills/<skill-name>/
├── SKILL.md          # Main skill definition
└── scripts/          # Optional verification scripts
    └── *.py

docs.title: Team Collaboration
docs.text: AGEN supports team collaboration features that help standardize AI agent configurations across team members and projects.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Team features allow you to:

  • Define required agents and skills for all team members
  • Sync configurations across projects
  • Enforce consistent agent usage
  • Lock specific template versions

docs.title: Initialize Team Config
docs.text:
agen team init my-team

This creates .agen-team.json in your project:

{
  "name": "my-team",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "created_at": "2026-01-29T00:00:00Z",
  "required_agents": [],
  "required_skills": [],
  "version_locks": {},
  "settings": {
    "enforce_agents": false,
    "enforce_skills": false,
    "allow_plugins": true
  }
}

docs.title: Add Required Agents
docs.text:
# Require specific agents for all team members
agen team require agent security-auditor
agen team require agent test-engineer

docs.title: Add Required Skills
docs.text:
# Require specific skills
agen team require skill clean-code
agen team require skill testing-patterns

docs.title: Remove Requirements
docs.text:
agen team remove agent security-auditor
agen team remove skill clean-code

docs.title: Version Locking
docs.text:
Lock specific template versions to ensure consistency:

# Lock a template to a specific version
agen team lock frontend-specialist 1.2.0
agen team lock clean-code 2.0.0

# Unlock
agen team unlock frontend-specialist

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text: Setting Description Default enforce_agents Fail validation if required agents missing false enforce_skills Fail validation if required skills missing false allow_plugins Allow third-party plugins true default_ide Default IDE for new team members "" template_source Custom template repository "" sync_interval Auto-sync interval ""

docs.title: Modify Settings
docs.text:
Edit .agen-team.json directly or use CLI:

# Enable enforcement
agen team config enforce_agents true
agen team config enforce_skills true

docs.title: Sync Project with Team Config
docs.text:
agen team sync

This will: 1. Check for missing required agents 2. Check for missing required skills 3. Install any missing components 4. Report what was added/updated

docs.title: Sync Results
docs.text:
🔄 Syncing with team configuration...

✅ Added:
  • agents/security-auditor.md
  • skills/testing-patterns/

⚠️ Updated:
  • agents/frontend-specialist.md (version locked to 1.2.0)

📊 Summary:
  • 2 agents added
  • 1 agent updated
  • 0 errors

docs.title: Validate Project Against Team Config
docs.text: agen team validate

docs.title: Validation Output
docs.text:
🔍 Validating against team configuration...

❌ Missing Required Agents:
  • security-auditor

❌ Missing Required Skills:
  • testing-patterns

⚠️ Warnings:
  • frontend-specialist version differs from lock (1.1.0 vs 1.2.0)

Result: INVALID (2 missing, 1 warning)

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
{
  "name": "acme-engineering",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "created_at": "2026-01-01T00:00:00Z",
  "required_agents": [
    "frontend-specialist",
    "backend-specialist",
    "security-auditor",
    "test-engineer"
  ],
  "required_skills": [
    "clean-code",
    "testing-patterns",
    "api-patterns"
  ],
  "version_locks": {
    "frontend-specialist": "1.2.0",
    "clean-code": "2.0.0"
  },
  "settings": {
    "enforce_agents": true,
    "enforce_skills": true,
    "allow_plugins": true,
    "default_ide": "antigravity",
    "template_source": "",
    "sync_interval": "weekly"
  },
  "members": [
    {
      "name": "John Doe",
      "email": "john@example.com",
      "role": "lead",
      "joined_at": "2026-01-01T00:00:00Z"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
Add team validation to your CI pipeline:

# .github/workflows/ci.yml
- name: Validate AGEN Config
  run: agen team validate --strict

docs.title: Pre-commit Hook
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# .git/hooks/pre-commit

if ! agen team validate --quiet; then
  echo "Team configuration validation failed"
  exit 1
fi

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Start Small: Begin with essential agents only
  2. Discuss Changes: Team-wide agent changes affect everyone
  3. Version Control: Commit .agen-team.json to your repository
  4. Regular Syncs: Run agen team sync after pulling changes
  5. Lock Carefully: Only lock versions when necessary for stability

docs.title: Template Catalog
docs.text: AGEN includes a comprehensive library of 20 Agents and 36 Skills.

docs.title: 📦 Agents
docs.text:
Agents are specialized personas with specific system prompts, tool definitions, and behavioral patterns.

Agent Role & Description Backend Specialist Expert in server-side logic, APIs, and databases. Code Archaeologist Specialist in reading, understanding, and documenting legacy code. Database Architect Designs schemas, optimizes queries, and manages data integrity. Debugger Analyzing logs, stack traces, and fixing complex bugs. DevOps Engineer CI/CD, infrastructure as code, and deployment automation. Documentation Writer Creates clear, comprehensive technical documentation. Explorer Agent Navigating new codebases and mapping dependencies. Frontend Specialist Modern web UI development (React, Vue, Tailwind). Game Developer Game logic, physics, and graphics programming. Mobile Developer iOS/Android development with Flutter, React Native, or Native. Orchestrator High-level project management and task delegation. Penetration Tester Security testing and vulnerability assessment. Performance Optimizer Profiling and optimizing application speed and resource usage. Product Manager Requirements gathering and roadmap planning. Product Owner User story definition and backlog management. Project Planner Task breakdown and estimation. QA Automation Engineer Writing and maintaining automated test suites. Security Auditor reviewing code for security flaws and compliance. SEO Specialist Optimizing content and structure for search engines. Test Engineer General purpose software testing and quality assurance.

docs.title: 🧩 Skills
docs.text: Skills are modular capabilities that can be mixed and matched to any agent.

docs.title: Verification System
docs.text: AGEN includes a built-in verification system that performs automated checks on your project for security, code quality, UX, and SEO.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The verification runner (agen verify) executes multiple check categories:

Check Purpose Security Scans for hardcoded secrets, vulnerabilities Lint Runs code quality checks UX Audits accessibility and usability SEO Checks search engine optimization

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
# Run all verification checks
agen verify

# Run with verbose output
agen verify --verbose

docs.title: Individual Checks
docs.text:
The verification system runs all checks by default. Results are displayed with:

  • ✅ Pass: Check completed successfully
  • ⚠️ Warning: Non-critical issues found
  • ❌ Critical: Issues that must be fixed

docs.title: Security Scanning
docs.text: Scans your codebase for security issues:

docs.title: What It Checks
docs.text: Check Description Hardcoded Secrets API keys, passwords, tokens in code Environment Files .env files not in .gitignore Security Anti-patterns Common vulnerability patterns Dependency Risks Known vulnerable packages

docs.title: Patterns Detected
docs.text:
The security scanner detects:

  • AWS Keys: AKIA... format patterns
  • GitHub Tokens: ghp_... format patterns
  • Private Keys: PEM header patterns
  • Credentials: Variable assignments containing credentials
  • Tokens: Variables with sensitive prefixes

docs.title: Lint Checking
docs.text: Runs language-specific linters on your codebase.

docs.title: JavaScript/TypeScript Projects
docs.text: Attempts to run: 1. npm run lint if script exists 2. Falls back to npx eslint . 3. Manual checks if no linter available

docs.title: Go Projects
docs.text: Attempts to run: 1. golangci-lint run 2. Falls back to go vet ./...

docs.title: Other Languages
docs.text: Basic file checks for common issues: - Trailing whitespace - Mixed line endings - Syntax errors in config files

docs.title: UX Auditing
docs.text: Checks HTML/JSX files for usability issues:

docs.title: What It Checks
docs.text: Check Description Alt Text Images missing alt attributes ARIA Labels Interactive elements without labels Touch Targets Buttons/links too small (< 44px) Contrast Basic color contrast issues

docs.title: Example Issues
docs.text:
<!-- Missing alt text -->
<img src="photo.jpg">  ❌
<img src="photo.jpg" alt="User profile">  ✅

<!-- Missing aria-label -->
<button><icon/></button>  ❌
<button aria-label="Close dialog"><icon/></button>  ✅

docs.title: SEO Checking
docs.text: Checks HTML files for search engine optimization:

docs.title: What It Checks
docs.text: Check Description Title Tag Page has <title> element Meta Description Has meta description OG Tags Open Graph tags for social sharing Canonical URL Has canonical link H1 Usage Proper heading hierarchy

docs.title: Example Issues
docs.text:
<!-- Missing title -->
<head></head>  ❌
<head><title>My App</title></head>  ✅

<!-- Missing meta description -->
<head>
  <meta name="description" content="...">  ✅
</head>

docs.title: Skill Verification Scripts
docs.text: Beyond agen verify, individual skills include Python verification scripts:

docs.title: Available Scripts
docs.text: Skill Script Purpose frontend-design ux_audit.py UX analysis frontend-design accessibility_checker.py A11y checks api-patterns api_validator.py API validation mobile-design mobile_audit.py Mobile UX database-design schema_validator.py Schema validation vulnerability-scanner security_scan.py Security scan seo-fundamentals seo_checker.py SEO checks geo-fundamentals geo_checker.py GEO checks performance-profiling lighthouse_audit.py Lighthouse testing-patterns test_runner.py Test execution webapp-testing playwright_runner.py Browser tests lint-and-validate lint_runner.py Linting lint-and-validate type_coverage.py Type coverage i18n-localization i18n_checker.py i18n checks

docs.title: Running Skill Scripts
docs.text:
# From project root
python .agent/skills/vulnerability-scanner/scripts/security_scan.py .
python .agent/skills/lint-and-validate/scripts/lint_runner.py .

docs.title: Verification Results
docs.text:
Results are displayed with severity levels:

🔍 Running Security Scan...

❌ CRITICAL (2 items)
  • src/config.js:15 - Hardcoded credential detected
  • .env:3 - Sensitive value exposed

⚠️ WARNING (1 item)
  • package.json - Vulnerable dependency detected

✅ PASSED (5 items)
  • No exposed sensitive values in environment
  • .gitignore properly configured
  • No SQL injection patterns
  • No XSS vulnerabilities
  • Dependencies mostly up-to-date

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Run Before Commit: Add agen verify to pre-commit hooks
  2. CI Integration: Include verification in your CI pipeline
  3. Fix Critical First: Address critical issues before warnings
  4. Regular Audits: Run verification regularly, not just at release

docs.title: Workflow Reference
docs.text: AGEN includes 8 workflows - predefined task automations that can be invoked with slash commands in supported IDEs.

docs.title: How Workflows Work
docs.text:
Workflows are Markdown files with YAML frontmatter containing:

  • description: What the workflow does
  • Content: Instructions executed when the workflow is invoked

Workflows are invoked using slash commands (e.g., /orchestrate, /deploy).

docs.title: /orchestrate
docs.text:
Purpose: Coordinate multiple agents for complex tasks.

Invokes the multi-agent orchestration system to:

  1. Analyze task domains (security, frontend, backend, etc.)
  2. Select 3+ appropriate specialist agents
  3. Execute agents in parallel or sequence
  4. Synthesize results into a unified report

Usage: 

/orchestrate Build a full-stack e-commerce application with user authentication

Key Features: - Minimum 3 agents required - Two-phase approach: Planning → Implementation - User approval checkpoint between phases - Verification scripts run at the end

docs.title: /deploy
docs.text:
Purpose: Execute deployment procedures.

Guides through deployment process:

  1. Pre-deployment checklist
  2. Environment validation
  3. Build and package
  4. Deployment execution
  5. Post-deployment verification

Usage: 

/deploy to production with rollback plan

docs.title: /plan
docs.text:
Purpose: Create structured project plans.

Generates a PLAN.md file with:

  • Problem statement
  • Requirements analysis
  • Technical approach
  • Milestones and deliverables
  • Risk assessment

Usage: 

/plan Implement user authentication with OAuth

docs.title: /brainstorm
docs.text:
Purpose: Ideation and solution exploration.

Facilitates creative problem-solving:

  1. Problem decomposition
  2. Alternative approaches
  3. Pros/cons analysis
  4. Recommendation

Usage: 

/brainstorm How should we structure our API versioning?

docs.title: /status
docs.text:
Purpose: Check project status and health.

Reports on:

  • Installed agents and skills
  • Configuration health
  • Pending updates
  • Recommendations

Usage: 

/status

docs.title: /preview
docs.text:
Purpose: Preview changes before applying.

Shows what would change without making modifications:

  • Files that would be created
  • Files that would be modified
  • Potential conflicts

Usage: 

/preview adding security-auditor agent

docs.title: /enhance
docs.text:
Purpose: Improve existing code.

Applies best practices and improvements:

  • Code quality enhancements
  • Performance optimizations
  • Accessibility improvements
  • Documentation additions

Usage: 

/enhance the UserProfile component

docs.title: /ui-ux-pro-max
docs.text:
Purpose: Advanced UI/UX design workflow.

Comprehensive design process:

  1. Deep design thinking
  2. Style commitment
  3. Layout diversification
  4. Animation and effects
  5. Quality verification

Key Constraints: - Purple is forbidden as primary color - No default UI libraries without asking - No standard/cliché designs - Mandatory animations and visual depth

Usage: 

/ui-ux-pro-max Design a landing page for a fintech startup

docs.title: Workflow Files Location
docs.text:
After installation, workflows are located at:

.agent/workflows/<workflow-name>.md

docs.title: Creating Custom Workflows
docs.text:
You can create custom workflows by adding Markdown files to .agent/workflows/:

---
description: My custom workflow description
---

# My Custom Workflow

Instructions for the AI to follow when this workflow is invoked.

## Steps

1. First step
2. Second step
3. Third step

Custom workflows are automatically discovered and can be invoked using /<filename>.
